unnormalised: The flyover project near Hebbal, Bangalore, is *finally* nearing completion, or so they say. After a delay of, oh, just a mere 36 months (give or take a few weeks!), the contractor claims it's 99.9% done. That last 0.1%, though, is apparently proving to be the Everest of engineering feats!
normalised: The flyover project near Hebbal, Bangalore, is *finally* nearing completion, or so they say. After a delay of, oh, just a mere thirty six months (give or take a few weeks!), the contractor claims it's ninety nine point nine percent done. That last zero point one percent, though, is apparently proving to be the Everest of engineering feats!

unnormalised: Reportedly, the total length of the flyover is 2.8 kilometers, a distance many Bangaloreans could probably crawl in less time given the usual traffic snarls. The initial budget was Rs. 150 crores, but sources whisper it's ballooned to a figure that could probably buy a small island nation.
normalised: Reportedly, the total length of the flyover is two point eight kilometers, a distance many Bangaloreans could probably crawl in less time given the usual traffic snarls. The initial budget was rupee one hundred and fifty crore, but sources whisper it's ballooned to a figure that could probably buy a small island nation.

unnormalised: The project manager, Mr. Sharma, assured reporters that the remaining work involves "minor adjustments." He didn't specify if these adjustments involved re-aligning the pillars by a few degrees or simply painting the whole thing in a more optimistic shade of orange. The estimated width of each lane is 3.5 meters, apparently enough space for a scooter and a prayer.
normalised: The project manager, Mister Sharma, assured reporters that the remaining work involves "minor adjustments." He didn't specify if these adjustments involved re-aligning the pillars by a few degrees or simply painting the whole thing in a more optimistic shade of orange. The estimated width of each lane is three point five meters, apparently enough space for a scooter and a prayer.

unnormalised: Citizens are cautiously optimistic. After all, theyâ€™ve been promised completion dates more often than free chai at an election rally. But hey, maybe, just maybe, they'll be zipping over Hebbal at 80 km/h soon. Or, you know, crawling at 8 km/h. Progress, after all, is relative.
normalised: Citizens are cautiously optimistic. After all, they've been promised completion dates more often than free chai at an election rally. But hey, maybe, just maybe, they'll be zipping over Hebbal at eighty kilometer per hour soon. Or, you know, crawling at eight kilometer per hour. Progress, after all, is relative.
